title: The Work of Martin Ravallion: A Round-up of Influential Research from an Exceptional Poverty Economist

last_post.content:
The year 2022 ended on a sad note with the passing of Martin Ravallion, one of the most influential economists working to measure (and reduce) poverty around.

If you’re just learning of Ravallion’s work, here’s a micro-summary of each of his 15 most cited (per year since publication) articles.

https://www.cgdev.org/blog/work-martin-ravallion-round-influential-research-exceptional-poverty-economist

Rest in peace, Professor Ravallion. My gratitude goes out to you for your leadership and your research.

title: Dark Alley – small god of Survived Hardships

last_post.content:
They say what doesn’t kill you makes you stronger, but that’s not always true. Sometimes what doesn’t kill you just makes you harder and more brittle, scarred and stiffened by the unwanted agonies of a world too big and too cruel for any single person to understand. Dark Alley understands that very well. Alley is the small god of the ones who survive. Not the ones who thrive, not the ones who pass unbroken, just the ones who somehow manage to keep standing.

Continue: https://leemoyer.wordpress.com/2023/01/04/dark-alley-small-god-of-survived-hardships/

The number of active Mastodon users — those who've logged in in the last 30 days — has fallen to 1.8 million from a high of 2.6 million. This reflects the fact that while there's a wave of new users after each Musk tantrum, the majority aren't sticking around. Even the 1.8M figure is inflated by new accounts, so I expect a further drop.

Still, the number of active users is over 4 times what it used to be before the Twitter takeover.

Source: https://api.joinmastodon.org/statistics (and Wayback machine).

title: Credit Freezes are Free: Let the Ice Age Begin – Krebs on Security

last_post.content:
Ok, I lied. That's not all. If you haven't done so already, consider making 2023 the year you freeze your credit, and maybe that of your partner/dependents.

KrebsOnSecurity has long urged readers in the United States to place a security freeze on their files with the three major credit bureaus. With a freeze in place, potential creditors can’t pull your credit file, which makes it very unlikely anyone will be granted new lines of credit in your name.

Also, credit bureaus make money by selling peeks at your credit file to potential lenders. They can't do that beyond institutions you already have a relationship with if your file is frozen.

https://krebsonsecurity.com/2018/09/credit-freezes-are-free-let-the-ice-age-begin/

title: Higher categorical symmetries and gauging in two-dimensional spin systems

last_post.content:
The most exciting thing I ever realized was that physics in n dimensions is governed by n-categories.

The reason is that you can use an n-category to describe what happens when you glue together chunks of n-dimensional space, or spacetime.

I got this idea around 1994 thanks to the work of Louis Crane and conversations with James Dolan. It's taking a long time for people to work out the consequences, but it really warms my heart to see progress like this:

https://arxiv.org/abs/2301.01259

(1/n)

title: Entropy Modulo a Prime | The n-Category Café

last_post.content:
@michael_nielsen This is not only of didactic value but has also led to new insights. For example, Leinster's paper introduces a curious (but similarly natural) notion of entropy modulo a prime. Here is a brief blog post about it:
https://golem.ph.utexas.edu/category/2017/12/entropy_modulo_a_prime.html

Leinster's paper also points out that entropy is like a logarithm on probability distributions since it is additive under the tensor product:
\[H(p_A\otimes p_B) = H(p_A)+H(p_B)\]
This by itself is a nugget of discovery fiction!

@michael_nielsen Btw, I consider any type of axiomatic characterization in mathematics as a form of discovery fiction.

For example, Shannon entropy was characterized by Faddeev as the only continuous function from probability distributions to real numbers that satisfies a very natural chain rule.

This is a simple way to motivate the entropy. The well-known formula with a logarithm then pops out of it by itself.

I first learned about this from a nice paper by Leinster:
http://arxiv.org/abs/1903.06961

title: Reducing Slack’s memory footprint - Slack Engineering

last_post.content:
This is an image of the decision tree that Slack used 5 years ago to determine whether to notify someone.

Every time you add a customization option like "don't notify me during these times in my time zone" or "mute notifications in this thread" etc, you add another branch or set of branches to a decision tree.

This is NOT a bad thing, but it is a reason that I am resistant to customization. Each knob you add expands software complexity and room for bugs.

Source: https://slack.engineering/reducing-slacks-memory-footprint/

More than a year ago, I wrote an article criticizing Irish DPC's interpretation of Facebook's legal basis.

This troublesome interpretation has [fortunately] been overturned by the European Data Protection Board which found that the ‘contract’ basis was not a lawful one for processing personal data for the purpose of targeted advertising.

👉 my article : https://verfassungsblog.de/why-are-you-on-facebook/
👉 a good article on the EDPD's decision by @bertuzluca
https://www.euractiv.com/section/data-privacy/news/facebook-instagrams-legal-basis-for-personalised-ads-found-in-breach-of-eu-law/

title: Filippo Bernardini, Accused of Stealing Book Manuscripts, Expected to Plead Guilty

last_post.content:
I can hardly wait for the (inevitable) documentary on this:
For years, someone impersonated authors and agents, editors and publishers, trying to steal unpublished book manuscripts from high profile authors like Margaret Atwood, Ian McEwan and Ethan Hawke, but also from debut novelists and writers of more obscure works.
Now, a resolution to the yearslong scheme is near.

title: De La Soul's catalog coming to streaming services for the first time

last_post.content: This is massive news. I've long believed that #DeLaSoul's crucial role in American musical history has been diminished by their absence from streaming services due in part to the #copyright clearance burden of their sample-heavy sound on the first few albums. I hope they get (re)discovered by Gen Z thanks to this! https://consequence.net/2023/01/de-la-soul-catalog-streaming-services/

https://noyb.eu/en/breaking-meta-prohibited-use-personal-data-advertisment The 390 million euro fine is only a small part of the story. As I predicted back in 2018 ( https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/monkey-cage/wp/2018/05/25/heres-how-europes-gdpr-may-take-down-facebook/ ), it looks like Facebook's business model is toast in Europe. "the European Data Protection Board (EDPB) has rejected the Irish DPC and Meta's bypass of the GDPR ... Meta has to get "opt-in" consent for personalized advertisement and must provide users with a "yes/no" option. The decision on a third parallel case on WhatsApp is delayed until mid-January."
